report_title: Fence and Scaffolding Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: Fence and scaffolding manufacturers have enjoyed healthy growth in recent years. Price-based gains related to climbing steel prices offset losses from downstream markets turning to substitute materials like wood or plastic for scaffolding and shoring products. While manufacturers enjoyed falling import penetration, the increasing value of the US dollar led to slow growth in exports. Industry-wide revenue has hiked at a CAGR of 2.0% through the end of 2024 to reach $3.2 billion, including an expected slump of 0.1% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Changes in Interest Rates Induced Volatility for Manufacturers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The low-interest rate environment following the outbreak of COVID-19 led to a booming housing market and offset considerable declines in nonresidential construction in 2020 and 2021. As interest rates climbed in 2022 and 2023, manufacturers began facing declines in housing starts and private spending on home improvements, hindering growth. Stagnating interest rates in 2024 will ease consumer pressure, allowing the housing market to recover. This will stimulate the need for scaffolding in the residential construction market.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Climbing Steel Prices Have Been a Double-Edged Sword
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While manufacturers enjoyed price-based gains thanks to a massive spike in the price of steel in 2021, these price increases have incentivized downstream markets to use substitute materials like wood and plastic. The increased use of substitute materials in nonresidential construction compounded already slow growth in that market. Some manufacturers have begun experimenting with composite materials of wood and plastics to get ahead of the market.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Manufacturers Have Encountered Mixed Trade Conditions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Fence and scaffolding manufacturers have enjoyed lower import penetration as the Chinese government mandated a contraction in steel production to reduce carbon emissions in 2023. Still, while imports from China have fallen, imports from India have surged, posing a potential threat to manufacturers. The strengthening of the US dollar in recent years has reduced export growth, subduing manufacturers' performance. Also, because fencing and scaffolding are relatively inexpensive and easy goods to produce, most countries fulfill their demand with domestic production.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers to Enjoy Growth in the Residential Market
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Stagnating interest rates are expected to lead to an expansion of residential construction activity, spurring growth in housing starts and private spending on home improvements. As steel prices level out, home buyers and consumers will be incentivized to proceed with renovations and decorative home additions like metal fences, boosting manufacturers' performance.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Nonresidential Construction Markets Will Be a Boon to Manufacturers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As inflationary pressures and recessionary concerns subside, nonresidential construction will return to growth and boost scaffolding and shoring sales. Also, considerable infrastructure construction investment will promote growth for manufacturers. While falling steel prices will lead to price-based declines, falling prices will incentivize downstream markets to use steel scaffolding and shoring over substitute materials.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers to Enjoy Favorable Trade Conditions
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Falling Chinese steel production will continue to reduce import penetration for domestic manufacturers and provide manufacturers with breathing room. Still, while Chinese imports are expected to slump, Indian imports will continue to threaten domestic manufacturers. As the value of the US dollar falls, manufacturers will be able to better compete with low-wage manufacturers abroad and enjoy growth in exports. Still, imports are expected to be minimal as local manufacturers fulfill the bulk of domestic demand.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures metal fencing, gates and scaffolding. The industry includes products made from purchased metal, as well as fencing and gates made at plants that draw wire.
key_trends: The residential market was a boon to manufacturers. Amid low nonresidential construction following the outbreak of COVID-19, growth in the residential market offset losses.
Fence and scaffolding manufacturers to return to growth. An uptick in nonresidential construction activity will be a boon to fence and scaffolding manufacturers.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market comprises specialty fencing contractors purchasing fences, gates and railings for installation at residences, businesses, sports and recreational facilities, parks and agricultural properties. Growth from specialty fencing contractors surged amid the housing boom following the outbreak of COVID-19. As housing starts and private spending on home improvements began to fall in 2022, this segment suffered.

This segment comprises general contractors (GCs) using products as temporary equipment during construction. They also install fences, railings and other products as permanent fixtures. Manufacturers enjoyed consistent growth from GCs performing work in residential markets over much of the period, but as interest rates began to climb, this segment shrunk.

This segment comprises home improvement stores, agricultural supply stores and online hardware and tool retailers. Other markets include construction equipment and fencing wholesalers and sales direct to end users (property owners). As fences have become easier to install and people have increasingly installed them themselves, sales to retailers and directly to end users have increased.

This segment comprises equipment rental companies, regularly renting wire fencing, scaffolding and shoring products for use on construction projects. Manufacturers frequently rent products to provide contractors with the flexibility to respond to major swings in demand, avoid the expense of storing unused equipment and keep capital costs low. High-interest rates spur growth from equipment rental companies.

products_and_services.product_description: Scaffolding systems are used to support workers and materials on construction or renovation project sites.
Shoring support structures are used under construction.
Protection systems include fences, gates and railings.
Other metal products include metal railings, window guards and temporary hoisting systems.

tier_1_suppliers: Metal Pipe & Tube Manufacturing in the US
Steel Rolling & Drawing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
Screw, Nut & Bolt Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Commercial Building Construction in the US
Home Improvement Stores in the US
Municipal Building Construction in the US
Industrial Building Construction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Scaffolding and fencing contractors work on various nonresidential buildings and structures within the commercial, industrial and institutional construction markets. Because of this, when activity in these downstream markets increases, and the value of nonresidential construction rises, revenue grows since contractors demand more fencing and scaffolding.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Most fence and scaffolding manufacturers are small-scale.
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Most manufacturers operate locally and regionally and the dispersion of demand for fencing and scaffolding products throughout the US makes it accumulate market share difficult.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Fence and scaffolding manufacturers' profit has dipped.
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Supply chain woes pushing up logistic and distribution costs have greatly hindered profit.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Purchase costs dip as input prices begin to fall.
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As steel and aluminum prices have begun to normalize after surging, purchase costs have dipped.

Manufacturers generate a substantial portion of their revenue from providing products used in the housing market. Fencing and scaffolding contractors are hired for smaller projects during the repair, maintenance and new construction of single-family homes. More extensive projects involve multifamily apartment buildings, typically requiring larger quantities of fences and scaffolding.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand from Bridge and Elevated Highway Construction
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Although less so for fencing, scaffolding services are necessary during the construction, repair and maintenance of bridges and highways. Demand tends to increase alongside the construction of bridges and highways.

The construction, repair and maintenance of utility-providing facilities require fencing, scaffolding and other products. Demand for contractors and manufacturers in this market depends on the level of government spending and overall trends in private infrastructure investment. As government and utility companies' budgets slowly recovered along with the economy, spending on utility construction has risen in recent years. An expected growth in the value of utilities construction will present an opportunity for the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_title: China's Control of Imports Has Wavered
international_trade_points.trade_description: Chinese fence and scaffolding manufacturers enjoy lower-wage costs than domestic manufacturers, enabling them to offer products for less, inducing import penetration. Still, the Chinese government limited steel production in 2023 to reduce carbon emissions, leading to declining imports. Beginning in 2019, the ongoing trade war between China and the US has depressed China's penetration of the US market.

Indian fence and scaffolding manufacturers enjoy lower-wage costs than domestic manufacturers, enabling them to offer products for less, increasing import penetration. India is a rising global superpower strategically located between China and Russia, two of the US's most prominent geopolitical adversaries. Strengthened trade relations between the US and India and an uptick in steel product manufacturing from India have increased imports.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports to Canada and Mexico are High
international_trade_points.trade_description: The top buyers of US fencing and scaffolding products are Canada and Mexico. Proximity to the two countries and the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), promoting free trade among the countries, fuels exports. Imports from the US are low because Mexico and Canada have thriving steel product manufacturing industries. Local manufacturers reliably fulfill the bulk of domestic demand.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports to the Dominican Republic are Climbing
international_trade_points.trade_description: The Dominican Republic has a fast-growing urban population, increasing the need for metal fences and railings. The US-Central America-Dominican Republic Free Trade Agreement fuels exports to the country.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is the most populous region, attracting manufacturers to serve residential construction markets. The Southeast is home to Florida which has the second-highest concentration of manufacturers in the country by state, contributing to the large number of manufacturers in the region.

The massive housing market and established manufacturing activity in California encourage manufacturers to establish in the state. Proximity to Mexico, the second largest export market for fence and scaffolding manufacturers, attracts manufacturers to the West.

Manufacturers in the Great Lakes enjoy proximity to steel producers in the region, reducing transportation costs of key inputs. Proximity to Canada, the largest export market for fence and scaffolding manufacturers, encourages manufacturers to establish in the Great Lakes.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Fence and scaffolding manufacturers must adhere to regulations regarding manufacturing operations, product quality, environmental issues and occupational safety standards, among others. Manufacturers are subject to federal, state and local environmental laws and regulations that relate to air and water quality, limitations on the discharge of pollutants into the environment and standards for the treatment, handling and disposal of toxic and hazardous wastes like fuels and oils used in the manufacturing process.

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) have set safety requirements and standards for producing scaffolding equipment. Manufacturers must also follow occupational health and safety, wage, overtime and other employment matters and dealings with state and federal government agencies. As with other regulatory matters, nonenvironmental issues can vary from state to state.

basis_points.basis_title: Price competition is high among manufacturers
basis_points.basis_description: Price competition is high among manufacturers.
The quality and availability of products are another source of competition.
Fence and scaffolding manufacturers face stiff external competition. Imports and products made from wood and plastic are substitutes for fence and scaffolding manufacturers' metal products.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Most fence and scaffolding manufacturers are small-scale
concentration_points.concentration_description: Most fence and scaffolding manufacturers are small-scale

concentration_points.concentration_title: Most fence and scaffolding manufacturers work in highly competitive local or regional markets
concentration_points.concentration_description: Most fence and scaffolding manufacturers work in highly competitive local or regional markets. Catering to a specific region allows manufacturers to cut down on transportation costs and form healthy relationships with downstream consumers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The localized nature of the industry and dispersion of demand throughout the US keep market share concentration low
concentration_points.concentration_description: The localized nature of the industry and dispersion of demand throughout the US keep market share concentration low.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Few manufacturers have the scale to accumulate a considerable market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry isn't very concentrated, instead consisting of many smaller manufacturers. One company, Assa Abloy Ab, has accumulated more than 5.0% of the market.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Larger manufacturers tend to operate plants abroad or use third-party manufacturers
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger manufacturers tend to operate plants abroad or use third-party manufacturers to source various products for the domestic market, diluting their market share and contributing to low concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Dip as Input Costs Begin to Normalize
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Key production inputs like steel and aluminum represent the biggest expenses and their prices are largely a function of the world market, fluctuating with supply and demand. Steel and aluminum prices have fluctuated recently, sometimes accounting for high purchase expenses and limiting profit. As these prices have normalized in 2023, purchase costs have dipped.

Wage costs have increased over the past five years, accounting for an estimated 18.8% of industry revenue in 2023. Manufacturers require knowledgeable and skilled employees to design and manufacture products. Wage costs have increased in line with revenue over the current period. The great resignation has hit the manufacturing sector particularly hard, forcing fence and scaffolding manufacturers to hike wages to attract and retain workers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: SUPPLY CHAIN WOES HAVE HINDERED PROFIT
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit has decreased over the past five years, accounting for an estimated 4.2% of industry revenue in 2023. Supply chain woes have increased logistics and distribution costs and hindered manufacturers' profit.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Fence and scaffolding manufacturers must attract and retain knowledgeable, skilled employees to aid in product design and manufacturing quality products.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Health of the Residential Construction Market
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fence and scaffolding manufacturers serve general contractors performing work in residential construction markets, so the residential market's health impacts volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The State of the Nonresidential Building Market
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fence and scaffolding manufacturers provide products to nonresidential buildings, so nonresidential construction market performance impacts volatility. Interest rate levels, corporate profit and general economic growth impact nonresidential construction activity.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: WROUGHT IRON FENCES WERE A BOON TO NONWIRE FENCE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: A surge in housing starts and private spending on home improvements following the outbreak of COVID-19 through 2021 led to an uptick in wrought iron fence sales, leading to growth in this segment.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by import penetration?
FAQs.answer: Rising imports lead to companies seeking efficient ways to cut costs and prices of goods to better compete.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Exports have offered a way for companies to generate revenue through foreign channels.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Steel prices in particular have affected industry operators.

FAQs.question: Is your company located near important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Companies tend to place themselves in locations near key suppliers of input goods, which makes it easier to produce their products.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology like 3D printing to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Companies are not investing heavily in new technologies like 3D printing.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Companies have been able to limit their wage bills by limiting employment.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulatory expenses have not significantly affected profitability.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: International tariffs have not significantly affected import and export products, but will affect related industries.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Investment in new equipment is common, with companies investing money each year in new machinery.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: One of the biggest financing challenges for companies include purchasing costs and the volatility of input prices.

FAQs.question: Does your company have close relationships with your supply chain? How can you cultivate these relationships?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry distribute their products through contractors, installation dealers, retailers and wholesalers. Control and management of distribution networks is a distinct competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: What affect does automation have on your profit? What is your budget for updating technology?
FAQs.answer: Through automation in production, manufacturers can reduce costs in an effort to undercut competitors' prices and maintain a higher profit margin.

FAQs.question: How much do you spend on inputs? How do you remain competitive with higher input prices?
FAQs.answer: The ability of manufacturers to negotiate long-term contracts for steel and aluminum or vertically integrate and supply their own inputs provides a key competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: How will interest rates impact demand for your products? What markets do you service that do not require substantial loans for projects?
FAQs.answer: As the yield on the 10-year Treasury note increases, so too does the average interest rate charged on loans by commercial banks, making large-scale investment in new construction projects more expensive.

FAQs.question: How much of your business comes from residential construction companies? How can you reach out to more companies in this sector?
FAQs.answer: Fencing and scaffolding contractors are hired for smaller projects during the repair, maintenance and new construction of single-family homes. Larger projects involve multifamily apartment buildings, which typically require larger quantities of industry products to complete.

FAQs.question: How has nonresidential construction affected your company's revenue? How will your company take advantage of increased construction activity?
FAQs.answer: Scaffolding and fencing contractors work on a wide range of nonresidential buildings and structures within the commercial, industrial and institutional construction markets. As a result, when activity in these downstream markets increases, industry revenue grows.
